intro: Leobordea lupinifolia, commonly known as the pink lupin, is a flowering plant native to the western regions of South America. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its leguminous properties and nitrogen-fixing capabilities. The plant features compound leaves with a distinctive pinkish hue and produces small, pea-like flowers that bloom in spring. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in coastal and mountainous areas. Due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits, it is cultivated in gardens and used in ecological restoration projects.
